creator: anipotts
title: Motion Sensor: Teach Vestibular
description: This project is designed to help science teachers build a motion sensor that can be used to teach the principles of the vestibular system, which is located inside the cochlea. The sensor visually demonstrates how the movement of hairs detects the direction of motion, turning on a light in the direction the sensor is moved, simulating neuron activation.
steps: Cut four small rectangles of conductive fabric. Iron Wonder Under onto the back of the rectangles, then iron these rectangles onto the back of the Neoprene piece, ensuring they do not touch.

Thread a needle with two lengths of conductive thread. Sew through the top of the Neoprene and conductive fabric, leaving an inch of thread at the end. Come back up close to the starting point, securing the thread, and repeat this process along the conductive fabric in a line.
Repeat the sewing process on all four conductive fabric rectangles.

Fill in the sensor's inside by sewing approximately three parallel lines of stitching, making sure not to sew these to the conductive fabric. Ensure the threads do not touch the outside threads connected to the conductive fabric, preventing constant light activation.

Attach the positive end of the battery holder to the positive end of the LED. Connect the negative side of the LED to one conductive fabric strip, and the negative side of the battery holder to the opposite side's conductive fabric strip. Repeat for the second LED and battery holder.
Create a strong connection by sewing through the LEDs and battery holders at least three times. When sewing onto the conductive fabric, stitch through the fabric a few times.
If sewing over previously completed stitching, use a small piece of felt as a patch, sewing through only the top layer to prevent stitching from crossing.
Insert the batteries and test the sensor. Stroking in one direction should activate one light, and stroking in the other direction should activate the other light.
If a light stays on constantly, separate the end threads from the center threads to break the connection. Secure knots on the back with Elmer's glue to prevent movement or fraying.
